title: 112_hr2557
content: Establishment of a Tick-Borne Diseases Advisory Committee. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will establish the Tick-Borne Diseases Advisory Committee to advise on interagency coordination, communication, and collaboration efforts related to tick-borne diseases. The Tick-Borne Diseases Advisory Committee will advise on coordination with other agencies, represent scientific viewpoints, and prioritize Lyme and tick-borne diseases. Members will be appointed by the Secretary from individuals outside the Federal Government. The Tick-Borne Diseases Advisory Committee will have voting members from the scientific community, tick-borne disease voluntary organizations, and health care providers with relevant experience. The Tick-Borne Diseases Advisory Committee will include health care providers, patient representatives, and state/local health department representatives. Members must have experience with tick-borne diseases. The Tick-Borne Diseases Advisory Committee will include diverse members representing various scientific perspectives relevant to their duties. The Secretary will also designate nonvoting ex officio members from federal agencies overseeing tick-borne disease activities. The Tick-Borne Diseases Advisory Committee will include members from Federal agencies such as the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, the National Institutes of Health, the Agency for Healthcare Research and Quality, the Food and Drug Administration, and the Office of the Assistant Secretary for Health. The Secretary will appoint the Assistant Secretary for Health as the co-chairperson, and members will serve 4-year terms with a public co-chairperson elected for a 2-year term. The Tick-Borne Diseases Advisory Committee members serve 4-year terms, with a public co-chairperson elected for a 2-year term. Vacancies are filled in the same manner as the original appointment, and members can serve after their terms expire until successors take office. The Committee holds public meetings at least twice a year, with additional meetings as needed, and agenda items can be added upon request. The Tick-Borne Diseases Advisory Committee meets at least twice a year, with additional meetings as needed. Agenda items can be added upon request, and meetings are conducted as required by law. The Committee submits an annual report to the Secretary detailing its functions, members, and affiliations. The Director of the National Institutes of Health submits an annual report to the Secretary, including the Committee's functions, members, activities, and recommendations. $250,000 is authorized for each fiscal year for the Committee's expenses under the Federal Advisory Committee Act. $250,000 is appropriated for each fiscal year to carry out the Act, used for expenses and per diem costs of the Committee under the Federal Advisory Committee Act. Voting members cannot be permanent salaried employees.
